conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to calculate both the average velocity and the average speed of the particle as it moves from point A to point C along two semi-circular arcs.
The particle moves from point A to point C along two semi-circular arcs, each with a radius of 1 meter.
Displacement is the straight-line distance between the initial and final positions of the particle, which is the straight horizontal distance from A to C.
The distance from A to B is equal to the diameter of the first semi-circle, which is 2 meters.
The distance from B to C is the diameter of the second semi-circle, which is also 2 meters.
The total displacement from A to C is 4 meters.
The arc length of a semi-circle is half the circumference of a full circle, which is π meters for a semi-circle with radius 1 meter.
The total distance traveled along two semi-circular arcs is 2π meters.
Average velocity is defined as the displacement divided by the time taken, which is 4 meters divided by 5 seconds, resulting in 0.8 m/s.
Average speed is defined as the total distance traveled divided by the time taken, which is 2π meters divided by 5 seconds, resulting in (2π/5) m/s.
The final answer is: Average Velocity = 0.8 m/s, Average Speed = (2π/5) m/s ≈ 1.2566 m/s.
